p: Whilst the combined effect of warming and acidification enhanced the biomass of primary producers ( p = 0.001; post hoc living biomass: OAT > control) and acidification enhanced secondary consumer biomass ( p = 0.034; post hoc living biomass: OA > control), warming ( T and OAT), irrespective of ocean acidification, caused a decrease in living biomass at trophic levels 2 and 3 ( Fig 2; S2 Table). Warming ( T and OAT) induced higher cyanobacterial biomass (ANOVA, F 1, 8 = 19.90, p = 0.002), replacing palatable turf algae at trophic level 1 ( Fig 3a, S3a Table). Consequently, energy was not transferred to successive trophic levels through consumption but accumulated as detrital biomass (ANOVA, F 1, 8 = 9.12, p = 0.017) ( Fig 3b; S3b Table) at the bottom of the food web. The system became less efficient in recycling the accumulated detrital biomass under warming ( S3 Fig; S3c Table; ANOVA, F 1, 8 = 9.31, p = 0.016), suggesting a collapse at the base of the food web.
